Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(2) Summary

One of the important aspects of platforms and platform engineering is to provide solutions for problems that occur in many APIs of a platform. This way API designers don't have to spend effort on solving the same problem over and over again, and API consumers can benefit from a more coherent design across the APIs of a platform. How to deal with problems that can occur is one of those questions that every API design needs to address. In this presentation we look at typical issues, some patterns and anti-patterns how to address them, and we also look at some standardized building blocks for representing those patterns. This allows designers and developers to spend less time figuring out what to do when everything is not OK.



Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(3) Getting APIs to Work

Designing APIs and Errors Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(5) HTTP APIs

  • REST APIs are a big part of many API landscapes
  • Most REST APIs are not technically REST but try to use HTTP well
    • For the full context check out the Richardson Maturity Model (RMM) [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richardson_Maturity_Model]
    • Most/many REST APIs today are RMM Level 2 (using various HTTP methods)
  • Using HTTP well means more than using HTTP methods
    • HTTP header fields support interaction semantics (authentication, content negotiation, conditional requests, range requests, â¦)
    • Media types support shared knowledge of message formats
    • Status codes support HTTP-level interaction models


Designing APIs and Errors Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(6) HTTP's Status Code Model

  • HTTP is the application protocol so status codes are on the HTTP level
  • Status codes allow generic software to understand protocol mechanics
  • Some status codes cannot be recovered from without intervention


Designing APIs and Errors Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(7) HTTP Status Code Categories

  • 1xx (Informational): The request was received, continuing process
  • 2xx (Successful): The request was successfully received, understood, and accepted
  • 3xx (Redirection): Further action needs to be taken in order to complete the request
  • 4xx (Client Error): The request contains bad syntax or cannot be fulfilled
  • 5xx (Server Error): The server failed to fulfill an apparently valid request


Designing APIs and Errors Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

Designing APIs and Errors Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(9) 401 vs. 403 vs. 404

  • 401 Unauthorized: Often used to represent lack of authentication
  • 403 Forbidden: Specifically represents lack of authorization
  • 404 Not Found: Generic message to prevent information leakage


HTTP Problem Details

HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(11) Better Problem Reports

  • HTTP status codes [IANA HTTP Status Code Registry [https://www.iana.org/assignments/http-status-codes/http-status-codes.xhtml] (1)] are useful but minimalistic
    • Well-defined semantics allow intermediaries to act on them
    • Servers may want to convey additional information
  • APIs may include problem details as part of their representation designs
    • Using a standard reduces the design work
    • Using a standard allows consumers to more easily understand the design
    • Using a standard allows sharing problem details across APIs
  • RFC 7807 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html]/9457 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html] defines a JSON-centric model for problem details
    • application/problem+json is a JSON-based representation of the problem detail model
    • application/problem+xml is an XML-based representation of the problem detail model


HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(12) HTTP Problem Details

  • status: Mirrors the HTTP-level status code
  • type: URI for identifying the problem type
  • title: Human-readable summary of the type
  • instance: URI for identifying the problem instance
  • detail: Human-readable summary of the instance


HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(13) URIs: Identifiers or Locators?

  • Caution: Relative URIs in type will get resolved
    • no-credits is a relative URI and not a string
  • type is an identifier for the problem type
    • tag:example@example.org,2021-09-17:OutOfLuck is an identifier but not a locator
  • type also can be used as a locator
    • https://api.example.org/widget/example-problem is an identifier and a locator


HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(14) HTTP Problem Details: JSON 

{
  "type": "https://example.com/probs/out-of-credit",
  "title": "You do not have enough credit.",
  "detail": "Your current balance is 30, but that costs 50.",
  "instance": "/account/12345/msgs/abc",
  "balance": 30,
  "accounts": [
    "/account/12345",
    "/account/67890"
  ]
}
  • http-problem-details.json


HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(15) HTTP Problem Details: XML 

<problem xmlns="urn:ietf:rfc:7807">
  <type>https://example.com/probs/out-of-credit</type>
  <title>You do not have enough credit.</title>
  <detail>Your current balance is 30, but that costs 50.</detail>
  <instance>https://example.net/account/12345/msgs/abc</instance>
  <balance>30</balance>
  <accounts>
    <i>https://example.net/account/12345</i>
    <i>https://example.net/account/67890</i>
  </accounts>
</problem>
  • http-problem-details.xml


HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(16) Avoid Error TMI

  • Avoid any implementation information
  • This is about helping clients
  • This is not about providing debugging information

RFC 9457: The New RFC 7807 Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(19) RFC 9457 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html] (July 2023)



RFC 9457: The New RFC 7807 Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(20) Differences between RFC 7807 and RFC 9457

  • There are no breaking changes
  • Three issues seen from usage in the wild
    • Registry of common problem type URIs (Section 4.2 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html#registry])
    • Clarification of how to treat multiple problems (Section 3 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html#problem-json])
    • Guidance for using type URIs that cannot be dereferenced (Section 3.1.1 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html#type])

(24) Scaling the API Practice: Platform Engineering

  • Platform Engineering = API Platforms + Consumer Support
  • Platform Engineering = DevOps + Scale
  • Platform Engineering = Consuming Services + Creating Services
  • Platform Engineering = Automation + Self Service


Standardizing Errors in APIs Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(25) Automating API Design Checks: API Linting

  • Various tools support API linting
    • Spectral [https://stoplight.io/open-source/spectral] has been around for a while and is widely used
    • Vacuum [https://quobix.com/vacuum/] is much faster and compatible with Spectral
    • Redocly CLI [https://redocly.com/docs/cli] provides an alternative on a different foundation


Standardizing Errors in APIs Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

Conclusions Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs

(30) Beyond the Happy Path

  • Use standardized ways of representing problem details
  • Identify, define, and share problem types for your APIs
  • Provide support for adding problem types to API designs
  • Make problem details part of your platform


Conclusions Erik Wilde: Everything is not OK: Representing Errors in API Designs
